Award.AbstractNarration:
Discrepancy theory studies various forms of the following question: How well can uniform distribution be approximated by a discrete set? This project is devoted to exploring fundamental problems and conjectures of discrepancy theory through the prism of harmonic and functional analysis. The strategic goals of the project are two-fold: to infuse discrepancy theory with new methods stemming from analysis, as well as to enrich the field of analysis with new problems and ideas. The program includes a wide range of problems and topics: understanding the precise behavior of the irregularity of distributions in various function spaces, producing new constructions of various low-discrepancy sets, investigating the correlation between discrepancy estimates and geometry, as well as numerous connections of the field to other areas of mathematics, such as probability and approximation theory.

The ideas and questions of discrepancy theory are strongly interlaced with other areas of mathematics: combinatorics, geometry, number theory, probability, approximation theory. Moreover, this field is closely connected to computational mathematics, namely, the methods of numerical integration, and thus, it has direct applications in science, engineering, finance etc. The scientific output of this project will expand and deepen the understanding of the underlying phenomena of discrepancy theory and its relations to other branches of mathematics, as well as yield important applications to science and technology. The results will be broadly disseminated through publications in high-level journals, presentations in conferences, seminars, and colloquia, active collaborations with researchers around the world, a number of educational and mentoring activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project deals with the fundamental questions of the following variety: how does one distribute N points in some geometric object in the most uniform way? And how large are the errors that inevitably arise in such distributions? These questions are very importnat in mathematics (approximation theory, numerical analysis, probability, combinatorial geometry etc), and in other areas of science (engineering, finance, statistics) which call for various multidimensional computations, such as integration, sampling, quantization etc.

The project studied this circle of problems through the prism of functional and harmonic analysis, the areas which study deep properties of functions by means  of various spatial and frequency representations. The PI has successfully applied numerous ideas of analysis to make important progress in the subject, devised new methods, and obtained many important results. In particular, significant advances have been made in the understanding of the long-standing open problem on the optimal  discrepancy of N points in the multidimensional unit cube. The PI studied numerous examples of well distributed sets, such as lattices and digital nets, and uncovered several interesting and unexpected new effects that govern the distributional properties of these sets. Special effort has been made to understand the connections between distributions of finite sets of points and the underlying geometry.

A very important aspect of this project lied in establishing connections between discrepancy theory and various other areas of mathematics: analysis, approximation, probability, combinatorics, geometry etc. While many of such relations were well known before, several new connections were uncovered in teh course of PI's work, and some others, which previously were only intuitive, have now been formalized. This work unified the knowledge of several areas and added to the understanding of the vast interconnections in mathematics.

The findings and topics of this project have been actively disseminated through publications in scientific journals, expository articles, numerous talks at conferences and seminars directed at various audiences. The PI also actively worked with younger researchers. In addition, the PI organized several events (conferences, research programs etc) directly pertinent to the theme of this project.
